messages.text: Temperature can vary greatly month-to-month. You need more time to see a pattern.
Short-term records can reflect natural variations in the climate system. What happens if you look at more years?
Climate trends become clear over 20 or more years of data. More time will show an even more distinct trend.
The rise in global temperature becomes very pronounced over several decades. What can you see in 100 years or more of data?
The world has warmed rapidly over the last century. The pace of warming has also increased—16 of the 17 hottest years on record have occurred since 2001.

annotations.text: Warming from both human CO₂ emissions and natural factors.
Temperature levels off, possibly due the cooling effect of aerosol pollution.
Warming starts to accelerate, driven by human CO₂ emissions.
Rate of warming increases to 0.3°C (0.5°F) per decade.
Sea level rise accelerates to 3 cm (1.1 in) per decade, doubling the rate of rise since 1901
Warmer oceans boost warming from greenhouse gases, breaking 118 years of heat records.
Historic heat wave in Europe kills 70,000 people.
Global average temperature breaks the 1998 record.
Russian heat wave kills 25% of the country’s crops, causing grain prices worldwide to soar.
Lowest recorded Arctic sea ice extent in the satellite record.
Australian “Angry Summer” peaks, setting a new record for hottest daily average: 40.3°C (104.5°F).
